data.title: The 40+ Best NBA Utah Jazz Power Forwards
data.meta_description: Over 200 sports fans have voted on the 40+ Best NBA Utah Jazz Power Forwards. Current Top 3: Karl Malone, Carlos Boozer, Thurl Bailey
data.text:
Ranked By

1.2K votes

225 voters

2 reranks

Voting Rules

Vote up the players who had the most success for the Utah Jazz

Big fan of Utah basketball? Then check out this list of Utah Jazz power forwards. It includes almost every power forward from throughout Utah Jazz history, including current power forwards and past ones. Featuring some of the greatest NBA power forwards of all time, the best Jazz PFs include Karl Malone, Carlos Boozer, Paul Millsap, and Andrei Kirilenko.

In the 2021-22 NBA season, the current Utah Jazz starting PFs and backup PFs are Royce O'Neale and Eric Paschall.

Who are the best power forwards in Utah Jazz history? Vote below and help decide the greatest Utah Jazz power forward of all time!

Most divisive: Danny Manning

Over 200 Ranker voters have come together to rank this list of The 40+ Best NBA Utah Jazz Power Forwards

Birthplace : Summerfield, Louisiana, USA, Louisiana

Nationality : United States of America

Position : Power forward

Utah Jazz: 1985–2003

The Utah Jazz recognized a gem when they drafted Karl Malone in 1985, as he went on to become the face of the franchise and one of the greatest power forwards in NBA history. Known for his gritty, physical play and incredible scoring ability, Malone formed a dominant duo with John Stockton that guided the Jazz to two NBA Finals appearances. Throughout his tenure with the team, Malone racked up numerous accolades, including two NBA MVPs (1997 and 1999), 14 All-Star appearances, and 11 All-NBA First Team selections.

Birthplace : Aschaffenburg, Germany

Nationality : United States of America

Team : Cleveland Cavaliers

Position : Power forward

Utah Jazz: 2004–2010

When Carlos Boozer signed with the Utah Jazz in 2004, fans were ecstatic to see how this rugged rebounder and low-post scorer would impact the team. His versatile style of play and aggressive attitude helped the Jazz reach the Western Conference Finals in 2007. During his time with the team, Boozer garnered two All-Star selections (2007 and 2008) and was named to the All-NBA Third Team in 2008.

Birthplace : Washington, D.C.

Nationality : United States of America

Team : Utah Jazz, Minnesota Timberwolves

Position : Power forward, Center

Utah Jazz: 1983–1992, 1998–1999

When the Jazz drafted Thurl Bailey in 1983, they knew they were getting a versatile forward who could score both inside and out. His long wingspan and defensive prowess made him a key contributor during the early years of the Malone-Stockton era. Bailey's dedication to the team culminated in him receiving the Jazz's Sixth Man Award in 1988, which further illustrates his significance to the franchise.

Birthplace : Izhevsk, Russia

Nationality : Russian

Team : Utah Jazz, Minnesota Timberwolves, Brooklyn Nets

Position : Small forward

Utah Jazz: 2001–2011

The Jazz scored big when they drafted versatile Russian forward Andrei Kirilenko in 1999. His unique skill set, which included shot-blocking, playmaking, rebounding, and scoring, made him an invaluable asset to the team. As a result of his efforts, Kirilenko earned an All-Star selection in 2004, three All-Defensive Team selections (2004, 2005, and 2006), and the NBA All-Rookie First Team honor in 2002.

Birthplace : Monroe, Louisiana

Nationality : United States of America

Team : Utah Jazz

Position : Power forward

Utah Jazz: 2006–2013

Drafted by the Jazz in 2006, Paul Millsap quickly earned a reputation for relentless energy and an uncanny ability to score around the rim. His relentless work ethic and tenacity on the glass helped solidify the Jazz frontcourt. Though his tenure in Utah didn't yield any individual awards, Millsap's impactful play and hustle made him a fan favorite.

Birthplace : Atlanta, Georgia

Nationality : United States of America

Team : Oklahoma City Thunder

Position : Power forward, Center

Utah Jazz: 2010–2021

Acquired by the Jazz in a 2011 trade, Derrick Favors quickly became a stalwart in the paint thanks to his shot-blocking and rebounding abilities. The combination of his athleticism and physicality made him a formidable presence on both ends of the floor. While he didn't earn any league-wide awards during his time with the team, Favors' impact on the Jazz's frontcourt was undeniable.
